description: Dark Green Metallic 1968 Chevrolet Camaro convertible, loaded with RS/SS options. Very nice solid intact body with great body lines, solid original floors and great panel fitment. Rally sport headlights that function as they should.  Black and white houndstooth bucket seat interior.  Very nice dash and gauges with white soft top and SS nose stripe.  Borg Warner 4-speed transmission, 12 bolt posi-traction rear end, 350 cubic inch replacement engine with Edelbrock intake and finned Camaro valve covers.  Power steering, power disc brakes and newer Vintage AC system. This American Dream Machine is rolling on New American Racing Chrome wheels with performance tires but they can be exchanged for the correct Camaro SS rally rims, trim rings, center cap and newer BF Goodrich White Letter radial tires.   EXTERIOR: Midnight green metallic 1968 RS SS convertible Solid original floors and great panel fitment Rally sport headlights Newer cowl hood SS rally rims, trim rings, center caps Newer BF Goodrich white letter radial tiresINTERIOR: Black and white houndstooth bucket interior Very nice dash and gauges New door panels White soft topMECHANICS: Borg Warner 4-speed transmission on the floor 12 bolt posi-traction rear end 350 cubic inch replacement engine Edlebrock intake Finned Camaro valve covers Power steering Power disc brakes Newer Vintage AC systemUNDERCARRIAGE: Solid original intact undercarriageWikipedia Information"The Chevrolet Camaro is an American automobile manufactured by Chevrolet classified as a pony car and some versions also as a muscle car. It went on sale on September 29, 1966, for the 1967 model year and was designed as a competing model to the Ford Mustang. The car shared its platform and major components with the Pontiac Firebird, also introduced for 1967.Four distinct generations of the Camaro were developed before production ended in 2002. The nameplate was revived on a concept that evolved into the fifth-generation Camaro; production started on March 16, 2009.The first-generation Camaro debuted in September 1966, for the 1967 model year, up to 1969 on a new rear-wheel drive GM F-body platform and was available as a two-door coupe or convertible with 2+2 seating, and a choice of 230 cu in (3.8 L), 250 cu in (4.1 L) inline-6 or 302 cu in (4.9 L), 307 cu in (5.0 L), 327 cu in (5.4 L), 350 cu in (5.7 L), and 396 cu in (6.5 L) V8 powerplants. Concerned with the runaway success of the Ford Mustang, Chevrolet executives realized that their compact sporty car, the Corvair, would not be able to generate the sales volume of the Mustang due to its rear-engine design, as well as declining sales, partly due to the negative publicity from Ralph Nader's book, Unsafe at Any Speed. Therefore, the Camaro was touted as having the same conventional rear-drive, front-engine configuration as the Mustang and Chevy II Nova. In addition, the Camaro was designed to fit a variety of power plants in the engine bay. The first-generation Camaro lasted until the 1969 model year and eventually inspired the design of the new retro fifth-generation Camaro.The first-generation offered a standard, Super Sport, and Rally Sport editions. In 1967, the Z/28 model was added featuring stripes on the hood and trunk, styled rally road wheels, and a 302 cu in (4.9 L) V8 engine."American Dream MachinesAt American Dream Machines, we typically have over 100 quailty classic cars and trucks in stock and for sale. We have everything from Corvettes to Cadillacs, Camaros, Mustangs, Mopars, GTOs, Chevelles, Bel Airs, Blazers and exotic sports cars. Our classics and muscle cars range from the 1950s to the 1970s. Our inventory is diverse and continuously changing and always growing! Our 1 Goal is to make you, our customer happy with the American classic and muscle cars we offer. We highly recommend that ALL CUSTOMERS call our knowledgeable, experienced staff and with Midwest values and have very detailed discussions regarding overall condition of any of our classics that you are considering getting in the drivers seat of. Our phone number is (515)-245-9100 and we are centrally located in the heartland of America, in Des Moines Iowa.  American Dream Machines occupies the historic 41,000 square foot Packard Dealership. We are one of the largest full service classic car dealerships in the Midwest. We have over 10 active Mechanic hoists, a body shop and detail bays that are used by our technicians to inspect, repair, upgrade and detail our cars so that they are ready to be delivered to your driveway. Please give us a call and we will be happy to help get your dream car to almost any location worldwide! ALL OF OUR PICTURES AND VIDEOS ARE REAL, ALL THE WAY AROUND! We photograph our cars in our professional photo studio for the best possible image accuracy and representation of the cars. We do this because of our commitment to the authenticity and quality of the cars that we sell and the commitment to our customers.
Distinct, iconic, and absolutely fast, this 1968 Chevrolet Camaro convertible is already appealing at its first glance... and that's before you hear the grow of the modern LS V8 power.

Ermine White is one of those great Chevy colors that adds sophistication.  While that's factory-correct for this car, you can tell by its glossy presentation that there have been investments in this Camaro over the years.  The white is the perfect canvas to add all the bold details.  This includes bright work on the thin wraparound bumpers, velocity-stack style hood, and upgraded Ridler 17-inch wheels.  They add to this Camaro's performance appeal, it's the car's dark side that really intimidates.  The blacked-out SS grille, rear panel, and iconic stinger stripe look terrific.  Because the folding roof is finished in black, this is the kind of drop top that even look great when buttoned up.

But when you do take the roof down, this classic gets a whole new dimension.  The factory-correct red interior looks fantastic against the white, and it's also the kind of color that adds to any sporty appeal.  So the interior adds another color into the mix, but at the same time, fits in with the car's overall theme.  Bucket seats and a center console is exactly what you want on a high-performance classic.  This sea of red is completed by the carpeting, door panels, and dashboard.  Plus, there's a nice hint of sophisticated wood-like appearance running up the center of the car and on the three-spoke sports steering wheel.   You have all the best driver equipment, including the auxiliary readouts in the center console and a Hurst shifter.  Plus, the SunTach prominently mounted on the steering column is an instant reminder that this is an enhanced machine.

The moment you pop the hood, everyone can instantly tell this classic Camaro has a very modern heart.  The 5.7-liter LS1 is a terrific fuel-injected V8 that has earned its stripes in everything from Corvettes to GTOs.  It has been correctly installed in the engine bay with all the right supporting components, including an aluminum radiator w/large electric fan and a custom Flowmaster dual exhaust.  Plus, you have complete control over this modern beast and its thunderous soundtrack thanks to the four-speed manual transmission.  We love the look of the upgraded wheels, they also are the key to allowing for better grip with modern performance tires.

This is the kind of project you would want to do if you had the time.  But instead this Camaro lets you skip to the fun part with the turn-key upgraded droptop.  So if you're ready to show off this weekend, you need to call today!
This thing is a beast! We get fast, ground shaking cars- this one had the shop talking. Has a pile of receipts for recent performance work. Gas undergone a body off restoration.

EXTERIOR: It is a factory born red car. Has a really slick repaint. Very smooth and glossy, can't even feel the stripes. Body is straight and solid. Has big intimidating cowl hood, you know something good is lurking beneath it. Upfront the grill is in excellent shape, new chrome bumper and emblems. Working my way back the windshield is new. Stainless trim around the windows and rain gutters have been replaced, wiper arms are polished, new mirrors, door handles, window seals, rear window is new. Door jambs are painted very nicely, the bottom of the doors are spotless metal, has new weather strips. In back it has a spoiler, new tail lights, gas cap and bumper. Has 15 inch rally wheels with nice trim, new BFG tires.

INTERIOR: Completely restored. Upgraded Quicksilver B&M shifter and leather Grant custom steering wheel. Dash area is beautiful- new dash pad, painted metal, new chrome knobs and vents. Even the speedo and gauges are new. Has tic-toc tachometer with working clock. Has stacked gauges in console. Carpet and custom floor mats are new. Door panels, armrests, upholstery have been replaced.
TRUNK COMPARTMENT: Clean metal neatly spatter painted. Has nice carpet liner with sewn edges.

ENGINE COMPARTMENT: Has a dyno tuned 468 big block with 543 hp and 568 lbs of torque! The motor is only 9 months old and cost $9,340. It has a set of ATK high performance aluminum heads, Edelbrock intake and big Holley carburetor with electric choke. Has a set of headers, HEI ignition and is dressed up beautifully. It's full of chrome parts including the water pump, alternater, aluminum pulleys etc. New chrome master cylinder and booster, chrome power steering. The radiator is upgraded with real nice aluminum with dual electric fans with aluminum shroud and overflow bottle. Engine bay is painted red including the underside of the hood.

UNDERSIDE: Very impressive. Clean metal floors painted red. Even the lower inner 1/4s are clean. Upfront the front end and steering is rebuilt. Has sway bar. High performance transmission is only 3 months old. From CBR transmissions. We have receipt ($3,446) and specs on the build. Has frame connectors. In back it has adjustable tubular control arms and gas shocks. And new gas tank. Has a real fat Flowmaster exhaust and if that isn't loud enough it has a set of stainless electric dumps. Hit the button and make some noise!
If you need a little excitement in your life, this ground pounder will deliver.

This model may not have been the first muscle car introduced, but cars like this 1968 Chevrolet Camaro certainly changed the dynamic of competition among manufacturers when they joined the action. Looking sharp, running strong and sounding awesome, this vintage Chevy will be a great score for the enthusiast looking to get behind the wheel of true classic that's ready to provide miles and miles of exhilarating driving.

It didn't take Chevy much time to get their prized project into top form. The first generation of Camaros debuted just a year before this '68 rolled out, and you can see just how this take on the long hood/ short deck lid/ broad track muscle car formula captured the immediate interest of the car buying public. Clad in a magnetic bright red shade with broad black painted stripes running the length of its hood, it's sure to draw attention. The hideaway Rally Sport headlights were a key design element that bore no resemblance at all to what the competition was offering and the deep black background into which they're recessed looks great against the rest of the exterior, as does the cowl hood. The badging on all four sides of this '68 is in good form, the bumpers fore and aft sit level and the cabin is surrounded by clear glass, all of which add to the car's already considerable curb appeal.

Climb inside and you'll be surrounded by an interior that's been brought into great shape while retaining its original look. Both the low backed front buckets and the rear bench seat don't look like they've seen much action, though some dye work on all four seatbelts will take things to an even higher level. The door panels also look very sharp and cling firmly to their steel frames, and the center console - which features woodgrain accents and a signature group of inclined rectangular gauges up front - presents very well. The dash area has received a thorough refurbishing, or possibly a replacement altogether, and features a shiny, straight and uncracked pad across the top, with very clear gauges in its cluster and every control knob sitting securely in place. Take a look above and you'll see a headliner that's in the very same condition. The trunk area is lined with a fresh gasket to keep the elements out.

Just underneath the hood, a 350 cubic inch V8 sits in one seriously tidy engine bay, surrounded by nicely routed wiring, fresh hoses and components that look like they've been scrubbed clean. The powerplant carries a 4-barrel carb and an Edelbrock High Rise manifold for some added power, as well as a Chevy-badged chrome air cleaner and chrome valve covers to enhance its looks. The engine is in very good form, pulling with conviction and sending out a great exhaust note while doing so, and pairs with a 4-speed manual transmission to give you full control over this muscle car classic. While its manually-equipped counterparts often offer a compromised driving experience with their notchy, inconsistent clutches, there's no such issue here - the clutch action on this Camaro is smooth and precise. An aluminum radiator sits up front to keep temperatures in check, bracketed by a pair of export braces in the front corners of the engine compartment to add a little more rigidity to the front end. Smooth power steering makes navigation easy, while power brakes at all four corners - with disc brakes up front - provide dependable stops as this Chevy classic turns heads on its 17'' American Racing wheels outfitted with Sumitomo tires.
If you're looking for a Chevy classic that's road ready and a blast to drive, you have to check out this 1968 Chevrolet Camaro. Call today!

This 1968 Pro Street Caramo is loaded with just about every go fast part you can imagine even a brand new set of tires fron and rear to go with it.  Under the Glasstek hood and between the glasstek fenders sits an evil 572 Cubic inch Big block Chevy that gulps down alcohol through a Ron"??s terminator injection system that is rated at 1475 cubic feet per minute. The air and fuel then flow to the pro filer rectangular aluminum heads into the Merlin block where this mixture is compressed to 14 to 1. This bad boy has way too many high tech parts to list everything let"??s just say it"??s very quick. Now what good would all this horsepower be if you had no way to plant it to the ground? Ok here we go. This beast of a ride has been back halfed using R.J. race cars four link with pro stock bars connecting it to the Strange center section housing 4.56 final gears. The final gears then send this massive power to the wheels via Strange engineering 35 spline axles that are connected to the wrinkle wall drag slick with 5/8 inch studs. Between the torque monster under the hood and the strange engineering axles is the workhorse powerglide 2 speed transmission which houses a nine and a half inch 4500 stahl converter which allows the engine to get deep into the power curve. I have pages of performance parts that have been shoehorned into this lighted "??68 Camaro for sale. I can tell you it all equals QUICK! All purchases may be subject to any applicable tax title & licensing fees.   For more information call the Nashville showroom at 615-213-1800 or email us at

A well-executed, high impact color scheme draped over a classic muscle car is always going to be a recipe for curb appeal, but this 1968 Chevrolet Camaro has even more going for it than that. With some serious power under the hood and several well-chosen aftermarket upgrades, it provides a driving experience very much on a par with its undeniable magnetism.

When this Chevy rolled off the assembly line, it was carrying a fairly sedate Ermine white paint job, so it took a blend of inspiration and craftsmanship to transform it into the ultra-bold street machine it is today. Its black backdrop is nice and even, and with a solid clearcoat sitting on top, has a strong shine. Get up close and you won't find anything to diminish your enthusiasm, but you will notice some great details. Those painted flames extending back from the front end have very sharp edges and you can even see some pearl in them that provides an almost 3D effect.  The aggressive hood scoop adds aftermarket cachet and really blends well with the car's other features. There's plenty of fit and finish on display to accompany this Camaro's high impact look - it's well aligned from front to back and you'll find a new windshield sitting up front, along with clean glass surrounding the rest of the cabin. The badging has been deleted off the front fenders to allow those flames to really stand out, but the remaining chrome is securely in place - both bumpers are unblemished and level, and some well-focused attention to the rest of the trim can bring the rest of the exterior to top form.

The black vinyl interior has been refurbished while largely retaining its factory configuration and it exudes some serious vintage muscle car mojo. Both the front buckets and rear bench seat show only very light usage and when you scan the rest of the cabin, everything looks very clean. The door panels and quarter trim in back appear to have been fairly recently installed, and a nice expanse of black carpeting runs the length of the floor. Climb inside and take hold of the custom SS-branded steering wheel and you'll find the original gauges still easily readable in the instrument cluster, joined by a tach mounted on the steering column and a trio of aftermarket gauges sitting at the front of the center console. In-dash vents are on both sides of the dash, and while this classic doesn't currently feature air conditioning, it did at one time and with the plumbing in place you'll be a step ahead should you decide to add it back. Everything looks good in the trunk area - clean fabric lines the floor and everything within view looks solid.

The theme under the hood centers on exhilarating yet dependable power. The 383 cubic inch stroked V8 sitting at the center of the very clean engine compartment starts easily, packs serious punch and teams with a rock-solid 3-speed automatic TH350 transmission. There's a nice collection of Edelbrock components on hand - a sharp looking air cleaner and valve covers enhance the powerplant's appearance, and a 4-barrel carb and Performer intake take its power game up a few notches. 4-wheel power disc brakes now sit at all four corners for plenty of stopping power and with power steering on board, this vintage Camaro is an easy navigator as it prowls the asphalt on a set of 18'' Eagle wheels - whose black color is a perfect complement to the rest of the car - outfitted with Riken tires.
This 1968 Chevrolet Camaro is sure to attract attention and is equipped for high-performance action. Call today!

Recently restored, frame off, Camero RS with original 327 engine.  The car has only 55 miles since the restoration.  The original 2 barrel intake, and the original hood goes with the car.  During the restoration all body parts were replaced except one door and fender.  This is a professional, concurs, restoration.  It has a high rise hood, original pattern houndstooth bucket seats, console with wood grain and instrument cluster.  Instruments include fuel, oil, temp, and battery.  It also has a Tick Tock Tach and power convertible top with glass window.  Another unusual feature is the fold down rear seat.  It has a rear spoiler.  The American Racing 17 inch wheels are 225R45 on the front and 275/40 rear. It also has A/C. Disc brakes on all 4 wheels.

In the market for a great looking, turn key classic muscle car of the highest caliber? This 1968 Chevrolet Camaro features an impressive array of top-quality components that provide it with outstanding performance, while an assortment of tasteful and skillfully performed exterior modifications give it a level of magnetic curb appeal that's sure to draw attention.

This '68 has a sleek, distinctive look that will stand out in any crowd. Its silver metallic paint is in very nice form, with smooth texture and just the right amount of flake to add depth and a nice, radiating glow in the sunlight. All of its exterior chrome fittings - including the front and back bumpers, door handles and trim - have received meticulous preparation before being coated in gloss black paint and the result is awesome. All the stylistic inspiration that's been heaped upon it hasn't come at the cost of precision - its doors, hood and deck lid open and shut smoothly and a closer inspection will reveal they're surrounded by nice, even gaps. The prominent scoop on the hood has been well-fabricated and hints at the serious power that lurks beneath it, and the rear spoiler sits well-fitted over the deck lid.

The black vinyl interior shows the same high standards and attention to detail found on the rest of the car. Up front, race-inspired ProCar bucket seats offer plenty of comfort, coupled with all the support you could want for more inspired driving and they blend nicely with the details of the door panels to each side and the factory-look bench seat in back. Climb in, and you'll feel the siren-like call to grab ahold of the Billet Specialties steering wheel and B&M floor shifter and let this street machine perform its magic. Look above you and you'll notice the headliner is nicely fitted and in great condition. Look below and you'll see an expanse of fresh black carpeting. The straight, fresh-looking dash area is a strong feature on this Camaro, as it's equipped with an assortment of Dakota Digital gauges in its instrument cluster that illuminate the cabin in blue, as well as a retro-style AM/FM radio with an auxiliary port to expand your audio horizons. The trunk area in back is clean and tidy.

This timeless Chevy classic will flat out perform. At the center of its well-detailed and orderly engine compartment is a 350 cubic inch crate V8 carrying an Edelbrock intake and Quickfuel 4-barrel carb on top that sits underneath an open-element air filter. It's been armed with a pair of aftermarket heads and a performance cam that gives it a nice lope and, having logged just 2000 miles, it's just getting broken in and sounds a great exhaust note out of its Hedman headers into its dual exhausts. It also features a great looking serpentine pulley system and a chrome fuel pump that add even more eye candy. The engine teams with a 3-speed automatic TH350 that's shifting with precision and a 4.11 rear end that equips it with outstanding off the line acceleration. The addition of a nicely-proportioned aluminum radiator with an electric fan will keep temperatures in check during more demanding driving conditions and power disc brakes on all four corners combine with smooth power steering to provide dependable stops and easy navigation. This very impressive Camaro rolls on a set of 18'' show stopping US Mag wheels with chrome perimeters and gun metal gray centers that are wrapped with BF Goodrich G-Force tires.
You don't often see the combination of exhilarating power and outstanding visual appeal offered by this 1968 Chevrolet Camaro. Call today!
1968 Chevrolet Camaro Z-28- One Family Owned Since New, Only 37,104 Actual Miles

Cruisin Classics is fortunate enough to offer to you this Documented, one family owned, original paint, 37,104 ACTUAL MILE survivor, 1968 Chevrolet Camaro Z/28. This is truly a rare find. It was Purchased New going from father to son on July 5th, 1968. The Dealer was Jack Maxton Chevrolet in Columbus, Ohio which is located just down the street from our dealership. The purchase is documented with the original sales invoice and Protect O Plate.

Finished in the factory Ash Gold with black stripes, this Z/28 retains 90% of its original paint. It has all original sheet metal, original glass, original trim and original interior except the carpet. The most important part is the drive train. It does come with a matching numbers engine, transmission and rear end.

The engine presently in the car is a 1967 327 block with all of the Z/28 302 components assembled to it. The original Holley Carburetor, factory aluminum intake, Z/28 cylinder heads, 302 crank, rods and pistons are all there. The original numbers matching block with factory VIN and suffix code need one head bolt threaded hole repaired to be put back into service. (See Pictures)

The engine has a few aftermarket parts added such as an MSD Ignition system, headers and roller rocker arms. It does have the factory deep groove pulleys, original air cleaner, fan shroud and the original radiator with the tag still attached. It has a Flowmaster dual exhaust system. The 4 speed is a Muncie M21 close ratio and is the original numbers matching transmission.
The rear end is a 12 bolt Posi with 4.10 gears and is the original numbers matching rear end assembly.

With only 37,000 original miles, the body and paint can be truly summed up as a Survivor. It has 90% of its original untouched factory paint. There are a few flaws and minor rust in a few spots. After all, it is over 50 years old. Overall, it is very, very presentable and the paint has a great shine after all of these years. It has 100% of the original sheet metal.

The factory tinted glass is still intact and the trim is still in good shape too. The trunk compartment still has the original splatter paint. The floors and trunk are rust free but early in its life the shifter tunnel was modified Vertigate shifter but has since been re-modified back to use the stock type fixture.
Inside the front lower valance panel, you can see factory GM chalk markings 68 Z in the center and the lower extensions and markings as well.

The engine compartment has had some painting on the firewall and inner fenders as they are glassier than original but it still has the factory emissions sticker on the back of the core support. The owner added hood pins to the hood back in the day when it was common to do so.

The interior is all original except for the carpet and is as nice as you would expect it to be for a 37,000 mile car. No cracks on the dash pad, all of the dash brightwork and controls are in good shape.  The door panels and seat covers are in beautiful low mileage condition. There is a vintage Sun Super Tach as well as a set of Stewart Warner under dash gauges that were added way back to give it that extra performance touch.
This Z/28 came with power front disc brakes and still retains the factory 4-piston calipers. It still has the original power brake booster but the master cylinder has been replaced.
All of the front steering linkage, steering gear box and the original ball joints are still intact and good. The front and rear suspension are original except for new shocks.

The car has 90% of the original front to rear fuel line with a fuel filter added near the gas tank. The fuel tank has been out of the car and painted silver but appear to be the original tank and sending unit.
The Original owner painted the underside with black Rust-Oleum paint years ago to help preserve the car.
There are no more modifications to the car other than a set of bolt-on Lakewood Traction Bars.
O6C                                     Build Date of June 3rd week

1968 Chevy Camaro for sale in our Chicago Showroom!  This resto-mod 68 Camaro is powered by a 350cu engine with an auto transmission.  It is badged as a 396 SS as inspired by a build from a popular TV show it does not have a 396 engine.  Some of the upgrades include LED tail lights and "??67 style hideaway headlights.  Brand new dual exhaust Custom Coy"??s Wheels new steering wheel Wilwood power brake system new shifter.  Complete new electrical system for head lights rear LED lights and stereo.  Repaired old leak in pan.  Topping it off the underside has been coated in rust proofing.  The current owner had the above mentioned work done within the past year and a half since their purchase of the vehicle.  This is a rather unique car has most of upgrades to the electrical systems and power systems have all been done but the drivetrain has not.  For anyone looking to get their hands on an already nice car but want to beef up the power this is your car!For more information on this well sleek "??68 Camaro contact our Chicago showroom at (708) 444-4488 or
. To see more HD photos and an HD video of the vehicle running and driving visit www.GatewayClassicCars.com.
